Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2009 12:08PM LoriL wrote: Hi Shay, My Chiropractor solved the tendon problem- he uses a lot of deep tissue massage to break up scar tissue that often develops with an injury like that. But, that is something you definitely would NOT want to do postop as I'm sure that deep tissue massage probably increases the risk for damaging the lymph system. So, I would suggest getting an accurate diagnosis and then taking it from there. No, I don't have lymphedema. I just check out this forum every now and then as I'm trying to learn all I can to prevent it. :-) Best wishes to you!
Posts.Title: Even minimal swelling sign of lymphedema? Pines LoriL

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2009 09:48AM LoriL wrote: Shay, I'll let the lymphedema gals pipe in with their expertise, but just thought I would post a quick response... Have you by chance had any pressure or injury to your elbow? The ulner nerve lies along the inner side of the elbow, and if irritated will often cause pain in the pinkie finger and ring finger. A while back (before surgery) I had a tendon issue in my elbow ("tennis elbow") which caused my forearm to swell a tiny amount and my pinkie and ring fingers to tingle. Resting my elbow on a hard surface for a long time made it worse. Just a thought...
Posts.Title: Even minimal swelling sign of lymphedema? Pines LoriL

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2010 04:27PM LoriL wrote: Yup, I agree- take them back. If you find that you really want a pair this summer, you can always buy them at that time. My little size 2 forms are fairly comfortable, but I still really look forward to the weekends where I usually go bra-less a majority of the time.
Posts.Title: Why do I "need" $$$ silicone breastforms? lovemygarden lovemygarden

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2009 10:38PM LoriL wrote: Amen! I don't know what my future holds, but I know who holds my future! We can rest in that....:-)
Posts.Title: Hello kelnied LoriL

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2009 03:23PM LoriL wrote: Spunkygirl- that Third Day song has been my "theme song" since I was diagnosed in April. Love it! That whole CD has songs on there that really speak to me. Kellie- The thing that I have learned the most through this whole cancer journey is how to truly submit myself to God's ways. It is sooo hard for me to do as I tend to like to control things myself!  But, I just kept telling myself that "I am not my own- I'm His" and He has it all under control. He knew that this was going to happen to us. He knows the final outcome, and He is going to pour on the blessings through this experience. I've seen it happen so many times in the past 4 months. I can't tell you how many positive things that have happened to me all because of this life changing experience. Blessings to you, dear!
Posts.Title: Hello kelnied LoriL

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2009 02:29AM LoriL wrote: As is often the case ever since I was diagnosed, I woke up wide awake in the middle of the night. Hope this doesn't get worse now that I am on Tamoxifen! :-)  Anyway, I'm putting this time to good use and praying for each of you right now....
Posts.Title: Hello kelnied LoriL

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2011 09:26PM LoriL wrote: mamaoftwo- Hello! I'm a runner and cyclist, have had bilat.mast. without reconstruction, and choose to not wear my prosthethes when working out. I used to wear a little "pre-teen" type of bra (without my prostheses) under my shirts while running outside and at the gym just to give the appearance of wearing a bra. But now I don't even do that anymore- I just go "flat" and LOVE the freedom. No boobs flopping around, and no sweaty bra sitting on top of my chest.
Posts.Title: Prosthesis and running/swimming mamaoftwo goldlining

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2010 10:43PM LoriL wrote: I LOVE not having to wear a bra if I don't want to! Before surgery I had deflated, flat little boobs (I had recently lost a lot of weight) that would flop into my armpits when I laid on my back. LOL I don't miss them one bit!  I have some little size 2 forms that I wear most of the time to work and church. But, the minute I get home, the bra comes off and I'm free! When I'm out running errands or working out at the gym, I don't bother wearing them. Occasionally I feel a little self conscious, but I honestly don't think anybody really notices. Even though it has been 8 months since I completed radiation, the cloth against my bare skin feels nice.
Posts.Title: I'd rather be flat than fake...I think. Suzybelle robinlbe

Posts.Content: LoriL wrote: Hello ladies, I'm trying to decipher if I have injured my hand, or if I am developing signs of lymphedema. Ironically, I have an appointment with my Oncologist tomorrow, but wanted to get your input. Backround: bilat. mast 5/09, 2 sentinetl lymph nodes removed on left side, radiation to left side due to margins not wide enough, Bicycle injury to left side 7/10- torn open my left elbow. My elbow healed nicely, and I'm very active and have been doing yoga, weight lifting, running, cycling, etc. No signs of lymphedema anywhere.  About a month ago I had some pain in the palm of my left hand- felt like a bruise, but never any swelling. I thought maybe it was a soft tissue injury in my hand, as I felt it primarily when I lifted weights. I tried not to use it too much, and the pain went away after a few days. Now a few days ago I noticed the pain again when lifting weights. I had a quite challenging yoga class the following evening, but it didn't seem to cause pain in my hand. Yesterday, however, I noticed some visible swelling only in the palm of my hand. It again feels like a "bruise" in the center of the palm of my hand when I push on it. I should note that I tend to be quite prone to "overuse" athletic injuries, and have always been that way. My dad, sister and I get things like tendonitis/bursitis and other "itis's" at the drop of a hat. I'm also battling some knee issues where my knee swells up periodically from a tendonitis. :-( Anyway, just today it dawned on me that this might be lymphedema and not a soft tissue injury like I had suspected. Any thoughts? Would lyphedema feel like a "bruise" when I push on it? Would it be odd to have swelling only in the palm but not the fingers and not the wrist/arm/elbow/chest? Please help me... I'm feeling a bit panicky right now....  Bilateral Mastectomy without reconstruction 5/28/09; Oncotype Dx 16- no chemo; Close margins so 6 weeks of rads followed by Tamoxifen for 1.5 years (discontinued due to side effects) Dx 4/22/2009, ILC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Swelling palm of hand- lymphedema? LoriL kira

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 01:54PM LoriL wrote: Thank you both, I appreciate it! I'm sort of kicking myself that I didn't consider lymphedema as a possibility when I first noticed the swelling. I guess I'm so used to various aches/pains/swellings in other parts of my body that I didn't think much about it. Thank you again! I'll let you know what I find out tomorrow.
Posts.Title: Swelling palm of hand- lymphedema? LoriL kira

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 09:34PM LoriL wrote: Kira and Binney, My Oncologist agrees that my hand swelling is from a soft tissue injury, not lymphedema. He said it would be pretty unusual for lymphedema to show up on the palm and not the dorsum, and also the pain that I have in it is more than what would be typical with lymphedema. Thanks again for the insight. Bless you both!
Posts.Title: Swelling palm of hand- lymphedema? LoriL kira

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2009 04:48PM - edited Jun 2, 2009 04:58PM by LoriL I remember thinking the same thing,"Are they ordering these test because they THINK it has spread elsewhere?" I had a bone scan, breast MRI and CT scan of chest/abd/pelvis. These were done prior to my bilateral mastectomy. It turns out that my doc ordered them to get a baseline, and also because I might qualify for a clinical trial depending on my OncotypeDX results.  I was very glad the tests were done, as I found it reassuring that they were all negative. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Is my doctor keeping something from me I should know? happytobealive happytobealive

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2009 06:15AM LoriL wrote: Every doctor is different- some don't like giving any results over the phone (good or bad). I wouldn't necessarily try to read in to it. Do your best to keep active and your mind off of things this weekend- I know that is easier said than done! Best wishes...
Posts.Title: Normal procedure for biopsy results? mlrbelle unklezwifeonty

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2009 05:31PM LoriL wrote: Howdy! I'm a marathon runner- running is such a great sport! I had a double mastectomy (without reconstruction) on Thurs. May 28th, got my drains out on Thurs. June 4th, and went for a 6 mile run on the 7th. The fact that you've been exercising prior to surgery will really help you bounce back quicker. Like Alo said, the energy level is the biggest hindrance. So, I just make sure that I take a nap and rest if I need to. Before I got my drains out, I just walked a lot.
Posts.Title: Return to running after surgery? Kate2z80 Kate2z80

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2009 02:32PM LoriL wrote: Christine, Too funny! I had briefly considered going for a quick run prior to my surgery, but the whole "Nothing to eat/drink after midnight" put a damper on that idea! It would have been a little embarrassing (as well as dangerous!) to go into surgery dehydrated. :-) But, that's me- I'm a bit of a renegade. I'm a cyclist as well as a runner, and I DID figure out a way to safely ride with those silly drains tucked into my shorts postop....! :-) Just a little word of caution, though.... do NOT decide to strap a exercise heart monitor on below a surgical site that is still numb! Now, THAT was a stupid thing! I didn't feel the pain/pressure and ended up with a plum-sized bruise. Yikes!
Posts.Title: Return to running after surgery? Kate2z80 Kate2z80

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2009 12:26AM LoriL wrote: I can't say for sure, but I do know if it does, it isn't very much. I've had gastric bypass surgery, and have to be careful with both sugar and artificial sweetners. Drinking the whole jug of barium didn't bother me a bit.
Posts.Title: the stuff you have to drink at the scan cookiegal Sher

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2009 05:39PM LoriL wrote: I was surprised at how little pain I had, and how quickly I was able to do my "usual things." I had one dose of plain Tylenol when I was in the hospital, and was easily able to wash my hair in the sink the next morning. The first day home I couldn't reach anything on the top shelf of my kitchen, but by the second day it was no problem- I had full range of motion on both sides. Everyone had suggested to buy button down shirts to wear after surgery. The tags are still on them, so I'm taking them back! In sharing these things, I certainly don't want to discredit those that have experienced a lot of pain. Each person's body is so different, and I'm sorry that it can't be as smooth as this for everyone.  The other thing that surprised me was how far those drainage tubes were coiled into my chest- at least a good 12 inches! Yikes!
Posts.Title: Things that surprised me after mastectomy Lursa5 Ariom

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2010 03:42PM LoriL wrote: Thank you for your suggestions! I'll keep doing what I'm doing and be careful with the icing. I've got a chest contusion, too, which makes even regular breathing painful. But, I'll try to do more deep breathing as well. The redness and swelling that comes from the normal inflammatory healing response seems to be getting better, and my left hand is now the same size as my right hand. So, I have to think that those are good signs. The ER doc had me stopping by everyday to evaluate it, and it's looking like I won't need IV antibiotics. So, I guess at this point it is just a "wait and see" situation. Thanks for your support!
Posts.Title: Badly injured my arm- suggestions to prevent lymphedema? LoriL LoriL

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2009 11:52AM LoriL wrote: I have a history of headaches/migraines, but had not had one for the past 2 years. About 2- 3 weeks into radiation, I had a 10 day stint of a constant lowgrade migraine. Then they went away and came back the week after I finished radiation. Again, lasted about 10 days. My Radiation Oncologist said it could have been from stress, but I honestly didn't feel stressed!  My theory is that there is a TON of natural chemicals released into our systems when there is so much tissue damage from radiation. Our body goes into "overtime" trying to heal the damage and it wouldn't surprise me if it triggered headaches. Best wishes!
Posts.Title: radiation headaches, anyone? karenn ggandara

Posts.Content: LoriL wrote: Hello ladies! I'm new to all of this, and have some questions for you... I had a bilateral mast. but will be receiving radiation to the chest wall as the mass was 2mm from the "deep" margin and there was some LCIS less than 0.1mm from the "lateral" margin. The mass itself was in the upper outer quadrant- on the edge of the breast tissue and really close to the axillary area. My sentinal nodes were negative, so I won't need any radiation to the axillary area. My incision from the mastectomy stops at almost exactly where the mass was. On Friday I went in for simulation and tatoo placement. I didn't really get a chance to talk to the Radiation Oncologist at that time. He just came in briefly to show the Dosimetrist where she should mark my chest, and they she did the rest of the scanning and marking. I know that I'm probably just being paranoid, but I am really worried that they are going to completely miss radiating the area where the mass was because they are purposely avoiding the axillary area! If I look at the tatoo that is over on that side, and visually draw a perpendicular line up, the area where the cancer was is OUTSIDE of that line. Is this normal? Is the radiated area ONLY withint the tatoo markings, or is it outside of there as well? Should I say something before they start the rads next week?  Bilateral Mastectomy without reconstruction 5/28/09; Oncotype Dx 16- no chemo; Close margins so 6 weeks of rads followed by Tamoxifen for 1.5 years (discontinued due to side effects) Dx 4/22/2009, ILC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Really worried- questions about margins and tatoos... LoriL LoriL

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2009 11:15PM LoriL wrote: Thanks, Ladies! I'll call tomorrow and set up an appointment to get all of the details.
Posts.Title: Really worried- questions about margins and tatoos... LoriL LoriL

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2009 05:16PM LoriL wrote: Hi again, Ladies! I called yesterday to see if I could set up an appt. to meet with my radiation oncologist before we start treatments. Instead, he ended up calling me back and answering all of my questions. I found out the type of radiation that I'll be receiving (3D), that it will be 5 weeks to the entire chest wall where the breast used to be and then an additional week to the suture line, and that the radiation field is not necessarily located between the tattos. The mass was right at the outer edge of the mastectomy suture line, so the boost to that area should cover it.  I think to further put my mind at ease I will have them show me exactly what that radiated area will be before we start. Thanks again, everyone!
Posts.Title: Really worried- questions about margins and tatoos... LoriL LoriL

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2009 06:24PM LoriL wrote: Wow, it certainly sounds like you have been through the mill, and my heart goes out to you! I agree with HollyAnn- put a complaint in with your state's Medical Board. For several reasons, I think it is MUCH wiser to address this in a professional way than to go the You Tube route. It might make you feel better to get it out there in Cyberspace, but in the end it really won't accomplish much. Keep in mind that he could certainly sue YOU for Defamation of Character if he catches wind of the You Tube video. And, if you are not financially in a position to sue him, my guess it that you would not be able to financially defend yourself, either.
Posts.Title: Opinions Wanted Regarding Public Complaint Against My Surgeon Pat634 melissa-5-19

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2009 07:17PM LoriL wrote: I will be starting rads next week, and then Tamoxifen after that. Both my medical oncologist and radiation oncologist said that they prefer that Tamoxifen be NOT started during rads- for the same reason that Kleenex mentioned. They said that they don't want the Tamoxifen to subdue any possible cancer cells as the radiation will be better apt to kill it if it is "active." From the research that I've read, this is an area of some controversary and ends up being more of a "provider preference" instead of any hard fast solid research to support it.
Posts.Title: Taking tomaxifen while going through radiation bqswnnhn09 1Cathi

Posts.Content: LoriL wrote: Hello ladies! I had a bilat mastectomy in May 2009 with a sentinal node biopsy (3 nodes removed) on my left side. I've been very careful about avoiding injuries, blood draws, BP readings on that side and have never noticed any swelling of any nature.  Well, this past Wednesday I had a bicycle accident and badly injured my left elbow. They cleaned it out and stitched it up as best as they could, and so far it seems to be healing nicely. The ER doc said that I'm not out of the woods yet as far as possibly needing surgery to further remove gravel and dead tissue. I also have a good amount of "road rash" on my entire left arm. I'm diligently taking the high doses of antibiotic that I've been prescribed, keeping the wounds dressed with ointment and sterile gauze, and elevating and icing my arm on a regular basis. Is there anything else I should be doing to hopefully prevent lymphedema in this arm? Thanks much in advance!
